question: A.02 [1.0 point] (1.0) Match each term in column A with the correct definition in column B. (Answers used only once) Column A             Column B a. Prompt Neutron      1. A neutron in equilibrium with its surroundings. b. Fast Neutron        2. A neutron born directly from fission. c. Thermal Neutron     3. A neutron born due to decay of a fission product. d. Delayed Neutron     4. A neutron at an energy level greater than its surroundings.

question: A.03 [1.0 point] (1.0) Five minutes after shutting down the reactor, reactor power is 3 √ó 10‚Å∂ counts per minute (cpm). Which ONE of the following is the count rate you would expect three minutes later?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 2, Section 4.6. For S/D reactor, œÑ = -80 seconds. Time = 180 seconds. P = P0e t/œÑ = 3 √ó 10‚Å∂ e -180/80 = 3.162√ó 10‚Åµ

question: A.04 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following describes the difference between reflectors and moderators?

answers.answer: a. Reflectors decrease core leakage while moderators thermalize neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 1, Section 2.8.9, page 2-63.

answers.answer: b. Reflectors shield against neutrons while moderators decrease core leakage.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 1, Section 2.8.9, page 2-63.

answers.answer: c. Reflectors decrease thermal leakage while moderators decrease fast leakage.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 1, Section 2.8.9, page 2-63.

answers.answer: d. Reflectors thermalize neutrons while moderators decrease core leakage.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 1, Section 2.8.9, page 2-63.

question: A.07 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following algebraic terms is the effective multiplication factor (Keff)?

answers.answer: a. Number of neutrons produced from all fission _ Number of neutrons in the previous generation
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 3, Enabling Objective 1.1, page 8.

answers.answer: b. Number of neutrons produced from fast fission _ Number of neutrons produced from thermal fission
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 3, Enabling Objective 1.1, page 8.

answers.answer: c. Number of neutrons absorbed in the fuel _ Number of neutrons absorbed by fission products
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 3, Enabling Objective 1.1, page 8.

answers.answer: d. Neutron production from fission in one generation _ [(Neutron absorption in the preceding generation) + (Neutron leakage in the preceding generation)]
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 3, Enabling Objective 1.1, page 8.

question: A.08 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which of the following changes in reactor power would take the LONGEST time? Assume the reactor is on a constant period.

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: P = P0 e^t/T, P/ P0 = e^t/T, Ln (P/ P0) = t/T. Ln(400/100) = t/T, Ln (4) = t/T = 1.386, answer (a) power manipulations would take the longest time to complete.
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e^t/T, P/ P0 = e^t/T, Ln (P/ P0) = t/T. Ln(400/100) = t/T, Ln (4) = t/T = 1.386, answer (a) power manipulations would take the longest time to complete.
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e^t/T, P/ P0 = e^t/T, Ln (P/ P0) = t/T. Ln(400/100) = t/T, Ln (4) = t/T = 1.386, answer (a) power manipulations would take the longest time to complete.
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e^t/T, P/ P0 = e^t/T, Ln (P/ P0) = t/T. Ln(400/100) = t/T, Ln (4) = t/T = 1.386, answer (a) power manipulations would take the longest time to complete.

question: A.12 [1.0 point] At the beginning of a reactor startup, Keff is 0.90 with a count rate of 30 counts per second (cps). Power is increasing to a new, steady value of 60 cps. The new Keff is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff0)/(1-Keff1) = (60/30) = (0.90)(1-Keff1); Keff1 = 0.95
Incorrect. REFERENCE: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff0)/(1-Keff1) = (60/30) = (0.90)(1-Keff1); Keff1 = 0.95
Correct. REFERENCE: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff0)/(1-Keff1) = (60/30) = (0.90)(1-Keff1); Keff1 = 0.95
Incorrect. REFERENCE: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff0)/(1-Keff1) = (60/30) = (0.90)(1-Keff1); Keff1 = 0.95

question: A.15 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following conditions will INCREASE the core excess reactivity of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Moderator temperature is higher than normal (assume negative temperature coefficient).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, pages 30 - 31.

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, pages 30 - 31.

answers.answer: c. Burnup of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, pages 30 - 31.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, pages 30 - 31.

question: A.16 [1.0 point] The term 'Shutdown Margin' describes:

answers.answer: a. the time required for the blades to fully insert.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 3, Section 6.2.3.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 3, Section 6.2.3.

answers.answer: c. the amount of reactivity by which the reactor is subcritical.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 3, Section 6.2.3.

answers.answer: d. the amount of reactivity inserted by all the rods except the most reactive blade and the regulating rod.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Volume 3, Section 6.2.3.

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the reason that Œ≤effective is larger than Œ≤ for U235?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a greater worth for the neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 12.

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons resulting in less leakage during slowdown to thermal energies.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 12.

answers.answer: c. The fuel also includes U238 which has a relatively large Œ≤ for fast fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 12.

answers.answer: d. The U238 in the core becomes Pu239 (by neutron absorption), which has a higher Œ≤ for fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 12.

question: A.18 [1.0 point] The count rate is 60 cps. An experimenter inserts an experiment into the core, and the count rate decreases to 30 cps. Given the initial Keff of the reactor was 0.9, what is the worth of the experiment?

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì Keff1) ‚Üí 60 / 30 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì 0.9); Therefore Keff2 = 0.8 ‚àÜœÅ = (Keff2 ‚Äì Keff1) / (Keff2 ¬∑ Keff1) = (0.8 ‚Äì 0.9)/(0.8¬∑ 0.9) = -0.13888

Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì Keff1) ‚Üí 60 / 30 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì 0.9); Therefore Keff2 = 0.8 ‚àÜœÅ = (Keff2 ‚Äì Keff1) / (Keff2 ¬∑ Keff1) = (0.8 ‚Äì 0.9)/(0.8¬∑ 0.9) = -0.13888

Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì Keff1) ‚Üí 60 / 30 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì 0.9); Therefore Keff2 = 0.8 ‚àÜœÅ = (Keff2 ‚Äì Keff1) / (Keff2 ¬∑ Keff1) = (0.8 ‚Äì 0.9)/(0.8¬∑ 0.9) = -0.13888

Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì Keff1) ‚Üí 60 / 30 = (1 ‚Äì Keff2) / (1 ‚Äì 0.9); Therefore Keff2 = 0.8 ‚àÜœÅ = (Keff2 ‚Äì Keff1) / (Keff2 ¬∑ Keff1) = (0.8 ‚Äì 0.9)/(0.8¬∑ 0.9) = -0.13888
